INTRODUCTION:
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Chaos Rising, is the first expansion pack to the Dawn of War II RTS game by Relic Entertainment. Although it uses the basic principles laid out by Dawn of War II, it adds new and interesting mechanics to the formula which makes this expansion unique in itself.

The player takes the role of the 'Force Commander' from the original Dawn of War II along with his band of Space Marines. Here, one year after the Tyranid Invasion, the  capital planet of Aurelia, long lost in the Warp, has once again emerged. It is now up to the Blood Ravens to find out what vile things it has brought from the depths of the Chaos infested Warp.

PROS:
+ Old Formula with new Mechanics: - The expansion adds a 'Corruption' bar that measures how much your characters and soldiers are tainted by Chaos. The player will now have to be more careful on their actions since certain events carry consequences that may drastically alter the story.

+ Carry Over Progress: - Rarely do I encounter a game that will allow a carry over of your save files with all (most) of your progress. Lucky for us, Chaos Rising is one such game.

+ Fun new Toys: - Extended Skill Tree, New Wargear, new Squad Member(s), some new Maps (also a CON, see below), and an extended story to the Lore of the Blood Ravens will keep the players entertained as they develop new tactics and builds for their Space Marines.

+ Squadmates Does not Die as easily: - This is just an observation on my part but it seems that the Squadmates of your Sergeants doesn’t die as often as they did on the original game. This is a huge bonus FOR ME, since I thought it was kinda 'wrong' that Space Marines died way to easily back in Dawn of War II.

CONS:
- Shameless Map Recycling: - Most of the maps from the original Dawn of War II game were heavily reused in this expansion where the devs just rotated the default camera angle 90 degrees and tried to pass  them off as new maps.

- Uneven Voice / Sound Levels: - The OST was great as was the Voice Acting, but the speech sound levels were not properly leveled. Some voices play very loudly which hurts the ears, others play softly that it is drowned by the background music.

- Too Short: - I found the campaign to short with fewer missions than the original game. Optional quest are a rarity which limits the possible enjoyment of Space Marine builds.

- Heretics: - Filthy Chaos worshiping Heretics.

CONCLUSION:
GOOD EXPANSION, I like this expansion and enjoyed playing its campaign. It has expanded the lore that surrounds the Blood Ravens Chapter by adding more mystery and intrigue to an already secretive Space Marine Chapter. The new Corruption Mechanic as well as the multitude of new Wargears and expanded skill tree shall keep the players entertained with new build possibilities and tactics.

It may be worth the full price for some people but seeing how short the Campaign was, I would rather have people buy it during a Sale. This is still a great game and should be bought at some point by people who liked the original Dawn of War II game.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40K Dawn of War 2 Chaos Rising is the standalone expansion to Dawn of War 2 and it shows in quite a lot of ways that THQ is not only capable of taking criticism, they can take that criticism and turn it into game fixes and improvements.

Perhaps most notably and most importantly, the single-player campaign. No longer will you be fighting the same battles on the same maps over and over again. Now every single map is a unique entity, properly designed filled with story and gameplay triggers. Although this does mean the campaign is a good deal shorter than in Dawn of War 2 the trade-off is well worth it. Instead of getting only a couple of good missions and a ton of generic ones you now only get good quality missions. This also makes the storyline more condensed as you no longer have 5 generic missions in between every revelation and it keeps your interest up much more efficiently.

The campaign meta-game continues to use the RPG elements from Dawn of War but introduces a new one, corruption. As you play through the game you will find corrupted artifacts and face gameplay choices that result in your heroes slowly turning towards Chaos if you give in to temptation. Although this mechanic is not fully realized, you can't join the forces of chaos, it does give you some interesting choices along the way and a fairly significant storyline consequence towards the end of the game.

Perhaps the most immediate impact of the corrupt mechanic is the various abilities your heroes can unlock as they give in the dark influences. Although many of the abilities feel like just filler a few of them are actually powerful enough that you might opt for corrupting one of your men just to grasp that power. The corrupted weapons work much the same way, some of them being immensely superior to their regular counterparts.

In terms of multi-player the situation is much as the same as in the main game, nothing has really changed except for the addition of a couple of new heroes in Last Stand. GFWL is still present as are the heavy duty matchmaking and connection issues.

Graphically and sound-wise nothing has really changed either, the game still maintains a high quality in both albeit some of that might come from my infatuation with the general art and sound style of the WH40K universe.

When it comes right down to it Chaos Rising is an expansion that improves significantly upon the main game and has taken several steps to correct mistakes made in the original. Although it is an expansion that focuses mostly on the single-player aspects of the game it still manages to feel like a total revival and come out looking superior in every way.

reviewText:
I have absolutely loved the Warhammer 40,000 series - I own almost all the games. The original Warhammer and Medieval: Total War are what pushed me down the deep rabbit hole of strategy games.

If you like intense, action-packed squad-based strategy games, then you will absolutely love this game. Warhammer (and Total War) are easily 2 of the granddaddies of real-time strategy.

I have to admit, however, that I do prefer the original Warhammer more than the sequel because that one was not entirely squad-based - it was an RTS with building management like the Age of Empires series and Rise of Nations (make buildings to train units). In this game, you do not build any structures, you only need to worry about controlling your squad members.

The aesthetics are spectacular - lots of special effects and carnage. I love that your equipment is extremely varied and actually looks different when you change it with new loot you've acquired. The music and sounds are great and appropriate for the gritty theatre of war found in the Warhammer 40,000 universe.

The controls are not too difficult to pick up, however, if you want to be efficient then you need to become comfortable using hotkeys to maximize your micro-ing ability (you will need to rapidly use skills against your enemies and items to buff/heal you). The learning curve is moderate to difficult - you will have an advantage if you are familiar with RTS-games and/or the Warhammer franchise. If you are new, the tutorial mission is very good - and actually pretty fun even if you already know how to play.

The Warhammer 40,000 universe is massive, with so much lore coming from the books (much like Star Wars {before it all got retconned =( }), and the story is very good - it continues after your actions from the previous games (including expansions).

Your characters level up throughout the game, and you can invest these points into different skills, unlocking abilities and perks at particular intervals. You can also outfit them with whatever (applicable) items you may find in your adventures. If you have lots of junk items, you can also trade them for experience, which is great for helping you level up faster.

During gameplay, you will do a lot of micromanaging to keep your squad alive. You will also utilize cover, flanking, and many of the skills (ex: anti-personnel grenades, warcry offensive buff) to help you survive each level.

If you enjoy squad-based strategy games that offer a good challenge, give this game a try. You may also come to enjoy the expansions.

Definitely recommend.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Chaos Rising is a real-time strategy / tactical role-playing video game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ for Microsoft Windows based on the fictional Warhammer 40,000 universe. It is the sequel to the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War video game series.  Dawn of War II features a non-linear interplanetary campaign, as the Space Marines. The campaign can be played either as single-player or cooperatively with another player through an online connection.

The game's campaign departs from those of its predecessors in several key features. One of the most notable departures is that there are no base-building elements, unlike in previous Dawn of War titles. Instead, the player chooses the units to be used prior to beginning a mission, cannot build new units once the mission begins, and has only limited reinforcement options.

Has serveral multiplayer modes of play.  Adds Chaos Marine, Elves, and Tyranid avatars.

Chaos Rising is set one year after the events of Dawn of War II and the defeat of the Tyranid invasion (as well as the Eldar and Ork forces) of sub-sector Aurelia. The campaign marks the return of the Blood Raven heroes from the previous game, the Chaos Lord Eliphas from Dark Crusade, Derosa as the new governor of Meridian, and the heretical Vandis.

New to Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising is the Corruption System. In the campaign there are often multiple objectives which will complete a mission; depending on which one a player chooses to complete, they will become more or less corrupted.

Dawn of War II had a very mixed reception. Many wanted to keep the base-building elements of 1, even though they did not fit the 40K world at all. On the other hand, 1 became so perfect with the expansions and the patches that II was definitely a culture shock. The game is split sharply in two, with an isometric, squad-based action RPG in single player and a fast-paced RTS chess in multiplayer.

Of those two personalities, the campaign was the weaker. The missions resembled one another much too much and posed very little challenge. Enemy squads could be taken out piecemeal before a slow, slow boss battle. The storyline and the Space Marine characters were interesting, however, and Chaos Rising completely fulfilled the promise of it's predecessor.

In single player, all the squads level up as you play, and since there are many more possibilities than resources in the skill trees, it pays to plan forward. You also get loot drops during and after missions, and choosing who uses what requires forethought as well. The actual combat is very intense indeed, with wave after wave breaking themselves on the Emperor's Chosen. You get to retry missions and keep the loot and XP, which is possibly too forgiving, but at least some missions have a turn deadline after which they fail. The campaign also has an interesting Corruption mechanic. The best gear is corrupted by Chaos, and using them or making certain other choices will take your heroes toward power and damnation, with boons and setbacks along the way.

The lore side of things is well-studied as always. If you find a powerful Heavy Bolter (a super-deadly machine gun, if you will), for example, it comes with a little lore blurb detailing how this master-crafted artifact ended the lives of hundreds of heretics and was then blessed by the priests of Terra. It is possible that lore professors are not happy but that is in their nature. The rest of us, whether it be ordinary 40K fans like me, or friends of good games in general, will enjoy Chaos Rising. Retribution perfected the multiplayer but those interested in a great single player experience should start here.

In light of recent events, I feel compelled to provide a much more thorough review of Dawn of War II - Chaos Rising. Though I personally find my own review adequate, certain individuals have brought to my attention the possible vagueness surrounding the review.

I have constructed my edited review following a suggested format by a hard-core fan of mine. I understand my position of power makes my gaming decisions influential to those around me. I wholeheartedly apologize for the lack of depth in my original review - I hope my fans can accept my blunder and gain some insight from my revisions.

Given the number of repeated requests by an even larger number of dedicated fans, I introduce my more detailed review of Chaos Rising:

Graphics: Wow. Where do I even begin? Let's just say that the graphics are exactly what you would expect from Dawn of War. I was absolutely thrilled that I was not let down. Sometimes when it is late at night and I've had a few glasses of wine, I sit there and ponder how the graphics of a game could be so epic. 10/10

Gameplay: If I've ever had an adrenaline rush in my life, this is where it's been experienced. The sheer excitement of the combat has truly knocked my socks off. The Force Commander is a Force to be reckoned with, hehe. Oh how I wish I could have his jet pack in my life. One can only dream. 10/10

Story: From the first second of this expansion, I was glued to my seat and my fingers glued to my mouse/keyboard. Will I become corrupted? I still ask myself that very same question each time that I play. The plot is filled with twists and turns that give another meaning to the words revenge and betrayal. Every distress call I receive leads to a rapidly beating heart - this forces me to momentarily exit the game until I am able to overcome the overwhelming story. 10/10

UI: The buttons look very button-y and things always happen when I click on them. I was sold from there. 10/10

Fun Level: I walk away from every Chaos Rising session thinking about how gratifying that last mission was. The only issue with the fun level in this game is it is so extraordinary that everything else in your life will pale in comparison. A wide circle of friends and acquaintances have attempted to bring as much excitement into my life by offering free sky-diving lessons or tours of Jelly Bean factories. reviewText:
I rate the game Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising 3/5. OK.

If you want more of the same campaign with the same characters as the original Dawn of War II game you should definitely give this add-on a try. However, there really isn't a lot else to this game except it lets you play as Chaos forces in the multiplayer modes and has multiple endings.

The single player campaign is nifty in that you can easily pick up your characters and their various customized skills and many of their items pretty much where the main campaign of Dawn of War 2 left off. On the downside though the final boss fight of this add-on's final mission is needlessly frustrating and very poorly designed. On the easiest difficulty, playing it twice I must admit I was unable to beat the game's final boss. The ending mission's boss fight is a LOT harder than any of the boss fights leading up to it (those I had absolutely no trouble with but fighting against Ulkair himself is ludicrously frustrating).

Perhaps the signle best thing about this game is how the single player campaign also has several endings and which ending you get seems to depend heavily on how you did and what choices you made in most of the previous missions of the add-on leading right through to the ending. These endings range from your main character being executed to you and your squad being proclaimed heroes (an excellent variety of endings). These multiple endings and the manner in which you must arrive at them (through the decisions you make over the course of the entire add-on) are a very welcome change from how most games tend to work, and the manner in which this game executes its multiple-ending structure well done even when compared to many other games which do have multiple endings. Getting one ending versus another in Chaos Rising is not so simple or easy as deciding between flipping one switch after the final boss fight versus another (as was true in Deus Es: Human Revolution). in Chaos Rising, which ending you get depends on what objectives you fulfill or not and what items you choose to use and not all along the way, almost from beginning to end.

Although the multiple-ending structure adds some potential replayability to this game, although the game itself, its story and which missions you have access to and what order they are arranged in is, for the most part, arranged in a fairly linear fashion and the frustrating final boss fight serves as a bit too much of a counterweight to this game's various strengths. Also, there are still no single-player campaigns which let you play as any force other than that of the Blood Ravens Space Marines from the original Dawn of War 2 and endings in the Warhammer 40K universe can be predictable due to the sheer implacability of the game's setting. Regardless of what you do, war is going to continue (and so sequels are going to happen) but this is true to the franchise.

reviewText: Dawn of War II had almost everything I like in video games: strategy, good pacing, character choice, and involving characters. The story in DOW II was good, and Chaos Rising doesn't disappoint in that regard. The new chaos race is a blast to play as and the upgrades to the other races are very welcome. In the single player, 10 more levels and the corruption system add depth and more choices. So while the campaign is pretty freaking short, it's easily replayable. I guess the shortness of the campaign could be the only weakness in this package, but come on people, it's an expansion pack! A company with a more renowned name might have released something like this as a sequel. Accept it for what it is: an expansion pack. For half the price of a regular game, I say this is a good deal. If you liked Dawn of War II, you will love Chaos Rising!

This game is a very good sequel. They kept everything that was good about the previous game, with some fixes to solve other problems.

1) DoW2 encouraged you to keep the same party: Not here. Refusing to take some units to some missions will make them corrupted by Chaos.

2) DoW2 wasn't very balanced: Sometimes, some weapons were simply better. Why bring a Missile Launcher when Thaddeus and a Thunder Hammer set-up will do it faster, quicker and safer? In this game, nearly every choice is equally good.

3) Equipment was easy to sort in DoW2: Not so here. There tends to be a lot of equipment which requires a lot from you. A weapon may be much, much stronger than other weapons, but will corrupt you. Only a little bit at a time, so do you risk it for a mission or two? Other weapons will be unable to be used unless you're completely uncorrupted.

There are a lot of other good points, but if you like RTS, play this.

This game is a very good sequel. They kept everything that was good about the previous game, with some fixes to solve other problems.

1) DoW2 encouraged you to keep the same party: Not here. Refusing to take some units to some missions will make them corrupted by Chaos.

3) Equipment was easy to sort in DoW2: Not so here. There tends to be a lot of equipment which requires a lot from you. A weapon may be much, much stronger than other weapons, but will corrupt you. There are a lot of other good points, but if you like RTS, play this.
